posts.name: BrianAtlanta
posts.cooked:
I’m trying figure what might be an issue that’s causing the this strange graph behavior as the result of using the characterization tool.  The Dynamic Velocity test’s velocity tests missing data and Acceleration-Portion Voltage graph.

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked:
frc-characterization’s acceleration is computed with a naive second-order central finite difference. The acceleration is basically noise most of the time, and there’s not much that can be done about it. We addressed a lot of data sampling and processing issues in the replacement tool SysId. We’ll be retiring frc-characterization for 2022.

SysId download: https://frcmaven.wpi.edu/ui/native/release/edu/wpi/first/tools/SysId/2022.1.1-alpha-3 Experimental docs for the new tool:

To use the toolsuite, we first need to configure the settings for your specific mechanism. Configure Project Parameters: In order to run on your robot, the tool must know some parameters about how ...

This tool will also come in the 2022 installer, which wasn’t possible with the old Python tool.

link_counts.title: Configuring a Project — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: You can trim most of the noise by truncating your data so that there isn’t so much of the steady-state data from the step voltage test.  This will help even with the more-robust implementation used in SysId, and iirc there might be a feature there to trim the data?

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked:
Oblarg:

iirc there might be a feature there to trim the data?

Yea, you can adjust the test duration to trim out steady-state data.

posts.name: BrianAtlanta
posts.cooked: Thanks, we were able to get path to work.  I’ll pull down Sysid and start playing with it.  I might be able to try it tomorrow.

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked: The new tool deploys a robot program with more consistent data sampling (so the data you start with is better in general), but you could also use sysid’s built-in JSON converter to analyze existing frc-char JSONs in sysid; the resulting analysis is usually better.

posts.name: BrianAtlanta
posts.cooked: I’ll make it a point to recharacterize tomorrow with Sysid.
